one_reviews_text:
In how many other VR games do you get to command and navigate your own starship, beam aboard other ships and/or space stations, grab tech from the enemies you defeat, upgrade your starship, command a starship crew, and travel through space???  Ummm... none that I can think of!!  This game awesome and by far one of the best VR games I own and have ever played.  I'd say try and get it on sale if you can, but if you can't, I think it's still worth the $40 (and I don't like spending a lot of money on games).  It's got some replayability, and don't get frustrated if you don't win the first or second or third time; that's part of the fun!

 The only downside I can think of is that when you lose, you lose; i.e. you start over from scratch with nothing and there is no going back to a previous save. It would have also been cool if you could interact with your crew.  All in all, I have really enjoyed this game in spite of these shortcomings.

Want a good VR Rougelike? Tired of all the teleport archer/mage games? Ever want to play FTL in VR with friendship, and actual away missions? This... absolutely this.  The only downside I see is not being able to move to abandoned ships and commandeer them but this is so much fun. I would say,  if you plan to purchase this game for coop, make sure you have friends that want the game as well. Online matchmaking is a rough go. Add me if you want to COOP! Would be fun to have others to play this with.

This was one of the first game I played on the Oculus Rift way back in 2017 and it was amazing for its time.  Teleporting to enemy ships or space stations and having shoot outs with space pirates or aliens was great.  I hope the devs can take this idea and update to the new hardware available and add some more options and gameplay.  I think it woudl still be great.  With the larger VR audiance of today, I think it coudl be a hit.  Not enough co-op multiplayer games for Quest.

I've enjoyed this game. There may not be much to it, but it's a fun little romp with friends.

I was planning on buying an extra copy to play with my wife, expecting to get a few hours of fun out of it, but it doesn't feel right to spend $40 on a four year old game that is no longer being supported or updated, with a non-existent online player base. Even most triple A game developers these days will drop their prices to under $30, usually $20 or below, once their game reaches its third birthday. Please, Gunfiregames, put it on sale or lower the price to something more fair for its age and lack of support, and people will buy it again, including me. Then I'll do a full playthrough with my sweetheart and write an updated review.

review_title: A demonstration of what VR can be.
one_reviews_text:
I was creeping around a space station that someone had asked me to investigate. They had a problem with bugs. The things were nasty beetles about the size of a dog that liked to spit acid. Not exactly pleasant but the money was good. I had the station mostly cleared apart from one last bug that was behind a secure door. As I walked through the station *ahem* acquiring things and looking for a security pass. SOMETHING LEAP OUT OF A VENT AT ME. I screamed so much my wife asked me if I was okay.

When it's good (with other players) this game is incredible, and even solo it's brilliant. It's honestly one of my favourite games of all time because even with the fairly limited structure and levels it *feels* like being in a sci-fi film from the 70s that only came out on VHS.

I don't think I've ever recommended a game to more people, and honestly I'm writing this review in part to remind the makers that there are people out there who still love it and would do terrible things for some DLC.

review_title: Dear 5 Stars: What Game Are You Playing?
one_reviews_text:
Is it the same game I'm playing?  The same unbeatable permadeath rando-mess of a game that is functionally unplayable alone?  I don't get it.  Why all the 5-star reviews?  What am I not getting?  Is there a great game bereft a decent tutorial?  Are you all playing multiplayer?  Is there something I'm not getting!?  What the ****, people!

It's taken me a long time to write a review of this game because I didn't want to admit that such a highly polished, visually appealing game could be built into a completely flawed and useless premise.  You need to gather enough resources to buy fuel to make jumps, but don't stay still for too long or you'll get overrun by unbeatable enemies.  But don't jump too many times either or you'll run out of fuel and get stranded.  There's no structure to the game because all encounters are randomized.  Sometimes you'll get your *** handed to you by over-difficult enemies before you've had a chance to gather more powerful weapons, other times you'll just run out of fuel and get run over by the enemy hoard.  Either way: Earth goes boom, Game Over start all over again.

Seriously, Gunfire, this game sucks.

It's a bit like you play Star Trek and FTL in VR! It's awesome boarding other ships with real players, hide behind cover and shoot the enemy. Moreover, you can do more than just shooting (hack stuff, disable the enemy's ship sub systems etc.)! 
However, there are quite 2 game breaking issues:
1) the game tends to freeze up somewhat once in a while with a black screen, forcing you to quit the game. Not sure if that's just me.
2) if the host/captain dies the game is over which kicks out EVERYone in your session (a design flaw in my opinion). That's really bad because often you did not get a chance to add people as friends. Even worse, players can't even tell who the host of the game is if you quick joined. Please change it so that the session keeps the connected players and simply restarts the gameplay.

Also, adding even more game features over time would be nice. I'm really glad it's not limited to shooting but this game shows how much more you can do in VR.

review_title: Best VR co-op I've played hands down
one_reviews_text: This is the kind of game that will have people  anguishing over failures and cheering over triumphs. It takes some experimenting and teamwork to figure how how best to progress and it really feels like your on this epic VR space adventure. This game has issues, such as the connectivity bugs that plague it ( you may want to consider adding players you meet to your oculus friends to stay in games in case you get disconnected), but once you really get games going and meet other players and work together to progress, theres no feeling quite like it.  This game is easily worth wading through the problems working against it, for players that arent afraid of the challenge this game presents. I feel the need to say to people who have tried this game and felt lthat THERE IS A PROGRESSION SYSTEM EVEN IF YOU FAIL. I do think that not making the achievement unlock progression system more apparent was a mistake, as it feels like a failed game really can feel like a waste of time until you find out that your achievements unlock better weapons/ships to start out with with each new playthrough. That said, this is a solid VR experience for anyone who enjoys a bit of a challenge, teamwork, and the sci fi setting for this gem of a game. I've never played or even heard of a rogue lite game before this, but im glad this game gave me the opportunity to have something truly unique to play in VR. For me, this is my "killer app"' for VR. Kudos to Gunfire Games on this one. ITS AMAZING!

review_title: Awesome game but needs work from devs
one_reviews_text:
To start off, this game is great. An entire galaxy you can explore for hours packed with exciting missions, space fights, and fun interactions such as trading with other ships or starting a full-on heist on an innocent traveler's ship. There are lots of different weapons to try and spaceships to take control of. This game is the right difficulty, difficult but not impossible. 

The bad part: This game has lots of bugs that the devs neglected to fix. 
In my experience I have encountered: 
1) Weapons dissapearing 
2) Being randomely kicked from a game
3) Bosses not working properly (In my case the main boss of the entire game would not move.)
4) Quests not initiating or working.
5) Even more I'm yet to discover!

One thing that I wish I knew when I started the game was that when you run out of crew members you have to restart the game (this can be frusturating if you have played for hours.) When you die you take control of a crew member on your ship. Crew can also be killed by pirate attacks, alien attacks, you, etc.

In conclusion: I would reccomend this game to anybody who has VR, just beware of bugs. Also, this game is most fun when played with other people for sure.

Really enjoy this game but it is extremely unforgiving. There is no save, no reloading. If you die, you respawn as one of the other 2 crew members until you run out and start over. If your ship is destroyed or runs out of fuel, you start over. Any mistake and you start over.

The game has great weapons, scenery and ship mechanics. The missions i found enjoyable though they can get repetitive. Hacking can be frustrating as there is no way to buy or make hack tools. Its random % chance you succeed and failure breaks it. If you have 0, probably start over if its early.  

Its a tough game solo. On an away missions you will run the risk of having problems on your ship that arent dealt with properly while you are gone unless you play with other people. 

 Made it to earth one time. They gave me 10 fuel, told me I was earths last hope, and then attacked and destroyed my ship because i hacked their command door to see their bridge and look for a collectible. 

Few things I would like to see

A difficulty setting where Easy lets you reload, normal is what it plays at now and hard for sadists. 

More ships to start with (unlocking is a loooong grind,  I still have 0) Some with more crew for playing with 3 buddies would be nice. 

Let players take other ships after clearing them and hacking everything. Hate leaving a ship with twice the everything to head back to my noob ship. 

Let players craft or buy weapons/hackers. I teleport over to every trade ship i come across to take theirs in tp bay, but eventually if you have a bad fight or no fights for a few jumps you can be left with too weak of a weapon collection to have much success at away missions. 

All in all , it is a great experience. If you are a star trek fan this felt so much more like star trek than Star trek did lol. The weapons were some of my fav in vr and its definitely worth getting.

review_title: Minor issues aside, this is a classic
one_reviews_text: IMO currently the best game out for VR.

Gameplay is a lot of fun, very replayable and works well for most part on multiplayer. There are some loose ends never patched up (several transactions don't actually do anything), a few bugs especially in multiplayer (models are invisible, ship lighting can get very dim on loads from saves where you exited game on another ship), and some quirks (like trying to drop any weapons without throwing them all over), but none of these impact the enjoyment too much. This would be an ideal game to open up to modding.

review_title: My Vote for Best VR Game
one_reviews_text:
Of course no game is perfect but this one is the complete experience.  The online 4 player drop in/out co-op experience pushes this game above others.

Let's take Skyrim VR or Fallout 4 VR they are amazing games to play in VR but no multiplayer.  To be able to play either of those big experiences in co-op would be amazing.  How about Borderlands 2 VR, it's an amazing open world game but they removed the co-op from it, still a great game but come on.

From Other Suns has lots of hours of play, unlockables, weapon rarity, bosses and other enemies can drop common/rare/epic weapons and items, u know the things that makes games fun.

The game also incorporates parts of FTL (u know one of the most amazing games ever made) and Borderlands co-op style gameplay.  It also has roguelite gameplay (if u die u start over), but u can unlock stuff to make ur next run easier and provides a challenge, even with experienced players ur still not guaranteed to finish a run.

review_title: Fun But With a Serious Flaw
one_reviews_text:
It was a decent game until my entire crew got wiped. I had five. But I came across a base infested with aliens that, not only did my weapons not scratch, teleported over (after ripping me to shreds) and ate my entire crew in minutes. Then the game erased my save. All the work I'd put into it - gone without warning. It wouldn't have mattered how good I was, it's not a difficulty issue. 

Otherwise, it could be a solid game. The graphics are decent and the immersion is above average. Hard to care when you know it could be gone in an instant, though. Two stars for the broken mechanic of 'instant wipe-out of entire save file with the single wrong choice.' 

Wouldn't buy again.

i'm not giving 5 coz there's still some minor issues, it's not perfect but great.
There's no first person body & reloading 's not fun ( just shake your weapon) it's not a big deal but immersion and fun, that's what i'm looking for in vr. Some boss have way too much hp, in maps with destructible covers, some will like it, i didn't. 
Lastlty, the game is complete, it's cool, but it also means no update or new content. If you don't mind those minor flows so this game is for you.

From Other Suns is definitely not a complex game, with some plot or characters full of personality. Despite this, it's fun to play with it, and I've always played this game in solo mode. What makes it special is the fact that after every "mission", the strategic aspect becomes increasingly important. You must choose the right weapons and use them with intelligence, choose the right equipment for your ship, plan your strategies according to the different missions. The only thing that bothers me is that the npcs are very linear in their behavior. When you shoot against an enemy, everyone knows automatically where you are, and no "stealt" tactics are possible.

Tried this one out during the latest free weekend, liked it so much I bought it. Fantastic immersion, love the arsenal of weapons, love coming across alien starships and teleporting to their ship to wipe them out and steal all their stuff (weapons, fuel, cargo). The map seams huge as their is allot to accomplish. Make sure you check your "Achievement Disk" in the captains quarters, because you UNLOCK PERMANENT WEAPONS!!!!  Yet another reason for me to love my Rift!

review_title: Good but could have been the best.
one_reviews_text:
This game seems needlessly cruel. 

You'd work hard to make several upgrades to your ship and a random attack, could end all your hard work. "Well that is how the game is supposed to be-" perhaps, but I don't feel like playing again for a long time after my shiny balloon has been popped. Fruitless grinding is no fun. 

Speaking of fun- the game is fun, especially with friends. It's immense fun, working together as a team, going on away missions. Then it all comes to a stop with no payoff, no climax, no resolution. It's hard to get people together to play VR. To get them all to buy the same game (or even try a free weekend) and the odds of getting together again and playing the same game multiple times is slim. So- I'm sure this game is mostly played solo. Which is lonely and hard. And half the fun.

I feel like this game could be im improved by allowing the player to continue from the last "jump" point after death. I know, it's against the spirit of the game- "it's supposed to be difficult dummy!" Perhaps have an easy mode, and make the way it is now 'difficult mode.' For people who beat the game in 'difficult mode' they could give out a "You're Better Than Those Easy Mode Losers" achievement to make it worthwhile. 

Besides the difficulty, there seems to be many pieces that could use some polish. Emphasize some aspects while de-emphasizing others. I feel like there is no hook to keep my interests. No reward system. From Other Suns hasn't been updated since it was released. It's worth mentioning. This is what it is ever going to be. I find that sad because one of the best all time VR games is 90% percent there.

Edit: Some people in their reviews have said, resetting makes the game fun. I would agree if deaths were due to something the player actually did, "oh I should've done this instead"- but as it is now an OP pirate appearing and saying "I feel like killing you." and then doing it is UNFAIR. Time invested in a single play could be 8 hours-- all lost.

review_title: Was Hoping For More, But Still Good
one_reviews_text:
First off my initial impression for this game was not great.  I had it on my list for a while based on the description, then it came up on a free play weekend.

My first three play throughs left me with a bad taste in my mouth.  My hopes were for a RPG style game with customization, freedom to roam, and some skill building.  So this is not like that.  This game revolves around building up weapons through random missions while you are jumping system to system trying to get to Earth.  The whole time aliens are getting closer and closer.  You have to keep moving away from the wave of aliens, while managing your fuel, ship ammunition, and crue members. 
If you run out of fuel you can't make anymore jumps to get to Earth, if you run out of ship ammo an enemy will destroy you.  IF you die and there isn't a crue member to spawn to, you stay dead, game over... no savepoint, all progress, and weapons lost.
That's what I didn't like about it.  I would get killed only having found a couple of guns, low on money, and I even ran out of fuel once.
I spent about 6-8 hours playing before I got the hang of it, and when I did I really learned to love this game for what it is.  
The action is sweet, I like moving like a real person, and ducking around corners for a fire fight. I finally got the hang of it, and by applying a simple principal - ROB EVERYBODY - I now have a wall full of guns, lots of fuel, and althought I was down to zero crew at one point , I now have two plus me.  Hoping to get to Earth as I understand it unlocks stuff for your next play through.

I'd still like to be able to upgrade, at least health and inventory slots (5 guns and 5 other stuff, not enough) and if someone took this style and turned it into a full RPG, I'd be in.  I wound up buying the game, and I'm here to tell you... if you get a chance to play this game before buying it, give it a good long test play, keep playing, dying, and starting over.  Eventually you'll get the hang of it.

Love this game so much.  Saw some complains about it resetting everything but that's what gives this game the replayability that I love.  Acheivements unlock new ships and permanent weapons, it's a blast!

My one critisizm is that I would love for an endless mode so that you can continue adventuring after you've saved Earth.  

Thanks!

This game has what it takes to be great. Unfortunately the current execution is not perfect for everyone and the game seems abandoned after one year of developers inactivity.
My biggest issue is the perfomance. My rig is an AMD FX8350/GTX1060, not even enough to run a stable 45fps. Since walking locomotion fits best the game style, motion sickness is incoming.
Changing settings don't change a lot, it's odd to see pixel graphics but still dropping below 45fps at the worst moments in every fight. Something went really south here.
Another issue (if you plan to play many hours) is the content. The storyline contains to many repetitive elements, some variation would really improve the game and there are so many options to bring variety to this game.
It's a shame that the devs let it down completly without even opening a gap for modding. Maybe they are to busy making a successor, I hope.
EDIT: Just dropped another star for another year of developer inactivity. UE 4.16 got many updates since they released the game. To bad we stuck with these lazy devs.

I played the free weekend.  Since its selling for half price, I went ahead and purchased it.  The game seems like it has the potential to be the best VR game out there.  But there is a ton of shortcomings.  I played last night and collected some great weapons. I joined this morning and it put me in a different toon with no guns.  I made a single jump, and my ship was boarded.  There I was with no weapons and it was all over.  Kind of stupid.  Just now I played.  I found a ship that was full of pirates.  I hopped on.  Killed a bunch of NPC's, and found some great loot.  However, I had no way to teleport back to my ship.  The I was on had its power online, but no systems were powered.  After an hour of looking around for a way to online the systems, I realized I was unable to get back and had to end the game.

Again, it seems like it can be one of the best games ever, so I went ahead and purchased it.  But I do hope the Dev's improve on some of the gaps in gameplay.

I'm having a blast in this game. It's a lot of fun to join up with other players in open games. But the game does have a lot of bugs and difficulty goes 0-100 out of nowhere. One jump and you can find yourself getting blown up by a pirate in one shot. I think it's basically mandatory to complete achievements over multiple plays in order to get unlocks to start with to get to the end. There are also many mechanics that I had to learn from other players because it was left out of the short tutorial.

Great Co-Op experience.

It can be grindy at times, and the enemies bullet spongey, however, the co-op mechanics are sufficent to overcome such shortcomings. This is one of the only games I find my self regularly returning to in VR (along side Echo VR and Rec Room).

Another criticism I'd level at this game, is that it has a lot more content than it might let on, and many players may spend countless hours without ever even knowing they are there.

I would suggest that the developers do more to guide the players towards such content (you're basically thrown into the deep end and expected to discover the mechanics of the game as you go), but it would seem the developers have moved on to other projects. The game has been basically abandoned and written off as completed, so don't expect to see any of the flaws being addressed in the future.

All that said a solid execution of what this game set out to do, makes this a title worth playing. In particular, with friends.

review_title: My go to game on the Oculus
one_reviews_text:
This is a great shooter. My only complaint is that it's too easy once you know what you're doing. Especially at early levels or when playing solo. My suggestion is to add an option (like a checkbox at the start) to treat the game as if there are always 3 people in it. As of right now, I usually have to limit myself to things like not using the medbay (only health kits), only using weak weapons (pistols, shotguns), and not crouching behind cover to keep the game challenging. 

The last mission should also be a lot harder. In my opinion, you should fail about 90% of the time attempting it. Right now the most difficult part about it is intercepting the enemy ship by predicting where it will jump.

review_title: Tons of fun if you worship RNGesus
one_reviews_text:
Not as deep as FTL, not as varied as Binding of Isaac, and not as challenging as either... but for a VR-based roguelite, this is far and away the best implementation of those mechanics. Tons of achievements (even if they mostly boil down to kill x number of this enemy/this ship and find x collectible), but having those achievements grant permanent unlocks in the form of more powerful starting weapons and ships is a nice little touch, a la Everspace.

Protip, join the From Other Suns discord server, the community there is super helpful and they're usually more than happy to help out newbies and will often guide you along your first several playthroughs in co-op mode.

Can't wait to see where this series goes!

I bought the game when it was on sale.  I did a lot of research and it seemed like an awesome idea and game.  The fact of the matter is, all of the compliants you have read are right.  
Aiming:  Very strange.  There are no crossairs or iron sights or scopes.  Aiming is a guessing game and ususally you have to fire a shot somewhere near your target to figure out the gun.
Empty World:  There is nothing to grab besides items that you can use.  There is a lot of clutter in some of the environments but you can not interact with them.  I am so used to being able to interact with the world in VR so it makes me sad when I can not pick up a coffee mug or move some boxes away.
Repetitive:  Now, this isn't a bad thing for me because I don't mind it.  Just putting it out there that people were not lying about that.  

However, I have not played it with others, so maybe it is a lot more fun and can help me forget about the things I listed.  It's a fun space game where you play as the crew and get to shoot laser guns at space pirates and aliens.  Get into tactical space fights and try to make it to the other end of space before an alien invasion does.  It has a lot of potential especially if you have friends to play with.
I agree that this is what Bridge Crew could have been if they added away missions; what it should have been. This game is fun single player, but gets tiring. Multiplayer is where it really shines.

Very fun game to play with friends. Some major cons that show up for me: no holding weapons with two hands, environments feel hollow as you cannot interact or touch anything in game areas, and missions can get a bit repetitive. Overall, it is a great Sci-fi coop shooter.

But feels empty, and the guns/enemies (which 90% of the gameplay revolves around) don't feel very responsive.

Apparently you can shake the guns to speed up the reload/overheat thing that happens, but this is awkward, and if it works I can't tell the difference. I would've much preferred some sort of reload that you actively do. Changing a battery maybe.

I was also disapointed that there wasn't 4 player multiplayer but only 3, but that doesn't affect how I feel overall. Overall a disapointing, overrated game, whos only fun moments came from other players.

For those that aren't familiar with the rogue-like genre, the whole idea is that you play until you die, and then you restart from the beginning. I've found a single run goes for around an hour which feels about right for a play session. I've yet to actually finish the game, so a complete run would obviously be a bit longer. Luckily, you can always save part-way through and come back to it if needed (although no re-loading a save if you die).

The game involves hopping from system to system across the galaxy in your spaceship, encountering other spaceships and space stations along the way, and completing various missions. Mostly you will be teleporting over to other ships and shooting everything in sight, but you can also choose to fire on the other ship, or simply power up your warp drive and jump away. This core gameplay is really fun and provides a great mix of exploration, action, and quick tactical decision making.

I've played about equal parts single and multiplayer and have had fun with both. I have only played online with friends however, so I can't comment on what the community is like in general. I will say that you will have a much harder time single player because the friendly AI is practically useless and you have very limited control over what your crew members do.

The production quality of the game is mostly top-notch. The voice acting is well done, the music has some cool moments (One of the themes is similar to the Avengers theme which is a bit cheeky, but it's cool so I'm not complaining), the visual design is excellent with ship environments that I just really enjoy exploring. Unfortunately the environments, though pretty, are almost completely non-interactive. There are handles that can't be grabbed and objects that can't be picked up all over the place. This approach to set-dressing just doesn't really work in VR. If it looks like you can grab it, you should be able to grab it. The other downer is that it is a bit buggy.

one_reviews_text:

What the game doesn't tell you is that even though you start over when you die, you are making progress towards achievements, which unlock permanent weapons and upgrades such as new ships. So the more you play, the more powerfull you are at the start of th e next game. 

In addition to this permament upgrade system, my favorite aspect of the game is the ship combat. I love exploring every nook and cranny of each ship in the hopes that I find a cool weapon or statue that I can bring back to my ship. In addition, this is definitely one of the longer experiences I've had in VR. I've probalby put in well over 20 hours and am still hooked. In addition I still have  many achivements that I have yet to unlock. I can easily see myself playing this for quite some time or at least until I have unlocked every ship and possible upgrade.

The visuals are great aside from a few animation problems. The soundtrack is very nice. And all that alone is the reason it gets a 4 star rating. My problems come down to the ship battles and the end of the game. All ship battles play the same. Knock out their shield or tactical depending on your weapon setup, and then kill them, that is, if you don't just board them and kill them from the inside. Which is easier and more rewarding anyway. And the last mission... I don't get why you go from dying in 3 hits throughout the game to being practically invincible at the end. It feels like we prepared everything and invested so much when we could've ran in with the 104 damage pistols and no healing and still do fine. Even with that disappointing end though, the rest of the game was still fun enough that I didn't have any regrets buying or experiencing this game.

First and foremost, doing anything but boarding an enemy ship is the wrong decision 100% of the time. Every slug-fest you get into with your ship's weapon is a garunteed uphill battle that you will almost always lose, and will never profit from. Scrap rewards for non-boarding actions are always less than the repair costs, and spending scrap on repairs will create a massive setback. It is, even with good purpose-built weapons, extremely difficult to disable systems from your ship. While boarding, destroying systems is as easy as poking around a corner and tossing a few bullets into it.

In terms of gunplay it's alright. The shake-controller-to-reload method is decent, but I cannot help but wonder why it could not be done by pressing the analog stick. In an intense firefight it's annoying to have to wildly flail your arms around in the hope that it realzies what you want, resetting your aim and forcing you to retreat. Boarding actions are, in the first 50% of the game, fun and engaging.

HOWEVER: Later in the game all enemies get personal shields (that you cannot get) and use cover-ignoring rapid-fire exploding shot weapons. The only option is to do the same yourself, and 9/10 times the best plan is to find corners the AI has to run around and shoot them as they walk stupidly around the corner before retreating and repeating. All fun is sucked out of the gunplay at this point as Cover is irrelevant, fighting is by ambush only, and if you have other players with you clustering together is garunteed death.

The Hack-a-tron system (Where you plug in a disposable item into a computer and wait for a dice roll) is infuriatingly simple and boring, relying on rare drops to unlock Cargo containers which become your main source of income. Cargo systems often have higher hacking levels than any hack-a-trons you have access to, which 100% garuntees you will not be able to unlock it. There is no way around.

Simple fixes could bring this from a cheap FTL clone into a great game.

Other than that, I really had fun playing this in co-op! Had some great laughs. But I'm done for now, unless there will be some update that improve upon what I've mentioned above.

review_title: Great framework one Big Change wish
one_reviews_text: This game was amazing good. I loved the fact you had both space combat and boarding action. The one thing about this game that left me wanting more was how the character progression is handled. Since you completely reset every time you die there was no attatchment to my ship or crew. Finding items that could be used to decorate was cool till I realized my next death reset it all. review_title: A great Time-sink to forget reality
one_reviews_text:
I played this game during the free weekend and was pleasantly suprised to find it to be a cool space FPS with alot of options for locomotion. If all you are wanting from the game is to simply complete it and move on then you will miss out on what this game truly has to offer. 

From Other Suns has alot of replayability with its cool but really rather short story, and its story is also rather simplistic. You will however, find yourself more than likely coming back time after time trying to snag the trophies and other achievements that can net you cool in-game rewards like new ships and sweet guns. The ability to have the adventure with up to 2 other pals for me is one of the best things about the game, as there is a vast number of great moments to be had with other people. The developers and the community are available through discord with LFG topics as well as the option to leave feedback and read about the updates to the game.

Overall this has been one of my favourite titles for VR and has given me many hours of fun and is one game i would happily recommend for anyone who is looking for a great game to enjoy.

review_title: Game Crash fixed. Game is OK.
one_reviews_text:
The developers have fixed the crash in the beginning of the game, in the course of a day, which is amazing.  So'I'm updating the review.

Updating my review from Good (4), to OK (3).  There just isnt enough variety AT ALL.  Ship to Ship combat is a chore, and you will fight the same enemies, over, and over, and over again. Everyone in the galaxy seems to have the same 3 issues, a rogue AI, pirates, or corrupted robot guards.   These are primarily the only three things you will see throughout your journey to earth.

So far, the game is OK.  Just good, not great, but really OK.  Playing just about any VR game coop with a friend always makes it better, and that is primarily what I have been doing.  

The visuals are great, shooting is great, but so far we have only encountered 1 type of "boss" after helping/raiding many stations.  I know this game is roguelike so we may see many new things later, but as of now, we've played for a few hours and nothing has changed much from the first mission.

I do like finding new weapons and stuff, BIG kudos to the shield.  It's awesome.  

So the way I see things is 1 Star unplayable, 2 stars sucks, 3 stars could skip it, 4 stars good, 5 stars great.  

This is OK, Enjoyable, and enjoyable with a friend. Try it out.

It plays slow and long, no problem with that. You pick stuff up, visit stations, kill a few things. It's not a quick wham bam game and it's pretty solid. Do wish I could jump and/or speed up the free movement but that's very minor.

My big beef that will stop me putting much more time into it now is permadeath. In other words, if you die three times, you lose all progress.

Maybe I expect something different but if I'm going to play a slower style of shooter like this that mixes a little trade, a little exploration, then surely I could keep my progress on single player?

Wouldn't be fair to knock more stars off as it's pretty decent in every other respect. I doubt I'll be playing much more as I don't have the patience to restart from scratch on a slow burn shooter.

I would love to give this game full 5 starts, cause the content of the game is rock solid. However with my current setup i have really big stuttering issues. My ryzen 5 1600 with 16Gb mem and GTX 1060 3Gb just wont cut it.
It seems that the performance of the gpu or system is not the issue but the vram that is filling up quite soon after the game launches.
At the moment game is only playable with all the settings put to low, and multisampling to whopping 0.5.
I really hope that this game would get a patch that would easy up the requirements for the GPU vram, cause buying a new GPU right now is not an option (there arent any decent GPUs anywhere!!)

While other current vr games may be more polished or have massive content (LE, FO4) they don't capture the raw fun of bouncing around the universe blowing things up and saving the world.  I just can't stop playing.
This is really cool game but i can,t play it so much. its the only game that gives me motion sickness

Several random encounter boss fights, lots of weapon variety, challenging gameplay, and multiplayer co-op make this a must-have title for hardcore VR players.

I've played a lot of games on Oculus and this is the best. I got this game the day it came out and I have been playing it almost non stop since. Just when you think you have got the game beat, you find another level.  WOW, that's all I have to say

review_title: Good, when you can connect to games.
one_reviews_text:
This game has an exceptional idea behind it. And it works like a charm, when you can connect to games or people connect to yours. But it doen't work all the time. Which is a big no-go for this game. I've probably spent hours already, with waiting for connections and getting disconnects from games and so on. (And no, my bandwith is not limited, as there are games that ran like a charm. ;) )

The second bad thing is the difficulty spike. Some bosses or enemies can be overwhelming, right after you had no trouble in the last fight. Which is irritating. Especially when there is permadeath involved.

But all in all, i can clearly say, this game is amazing. Even though it's a shame there won't be coming content updates, not sure but it doesn't look that way.

If you like ftl, this is the game for you. If you like having fun with other peeps, this game is also for you. 

Good VR multiplayer experience. Hope there are more games like this coming next year!
This is a great game, and one of my favorite.

I’ve been playing this solo almost nonstop for the past four days.  It’s one of the most fun and addictive games I’ve played (VR or regular).


If you’ve played FTL you’ll recognise the overall premise; make your way back to Earth (on the east of the map) while being pursued by aliens from the west.  Each jump consumes one fuel and may or may not lead to an away mission, a chance to resupply or upgrade.  The closer you get to Earth the more difficult the missions become. 

You start with three crew which represent your lives but can pick up more as you go.  If all your crew are kill, or your ship destroyed its game over.  But progression comes from an achievement system which allows you to unlock legendary starting weapons and more ships.


There are a number of locomotion settings.  After trying comfort I switched to full movement which I found very comfortable with no nausea despite the fast pace and playing for hours at a time.  Both standing and seated also work fine.

Can we get better locomotion, perhaps similar to Robo Recall or Raw Data?
How about a single play campaign?
Can we customize our characters? I played yesterday with a guy who didn't know his avatar was a female.

review_title: Best game in a long time hands down
one_reviews_text: Looks great with good arcade feel and alot of things to do. Another really great Rift title, so glad I got it.

I really really like this game. The graphics are great and the soundtrack is next to none. The thing that really bothers me about this game is that without a committed group of people playing together on a dedicated host's server, the game sucks a lot. As a fan of FTL, I think it's almost my perfect VR experience.
Unfortunately, it's not geared towards solo play as the AI crew can't come on missions with you, and you can't talk to them, give them weapons or issue commands once youre on another ship.
Introducing some simple RPG elements and customisation to the player and crew would be very welcome.
I love the loot system and I'm always excited to find and play with new weapons. 
The procedurally generated levels are really well done, and in the future I'd love to see more mission variations, enemy types, interior types etc. 

In other words, I really hope this game does well, and the devs get the double the funds to create From Other Suns - The Directors cut.

review_title: Bugs Drag Down an Otherwise 4 Star Game
one_reviews_text:
This is one of my favorite games to play with a friend, but we encounter bugs every game, and because there are no manual saves and the game is rogue-like, even small bugs can be game-ending, even if not game-breaking.

Today, 1/5/18, over three sessions, we had a full game crash during a jump, and one of us lost all our wepons upon reload.  The tactical station "hologram" frequently would not generate text or icons, meaning only the captain can access tactical, as well as other small visual glitches.

As far as content, it is almost entirely a thematic copy of "FTL," but it has less compelling story elements (everyone you meet is either a pirate or trader, or a station with pirates or traders) and weaker ship-based gameplay (fewer systems, less galaxy exploration, weird difficulty spikes) though it of course adds VR and FPS which are quite fun.  

There isn't a lot of ship or character variation, though the VOs are good and the character models are as well.  I wish they had animated mouth movement for players like in Star Trek Bridge Crew.

I really want this to be my favorite VR game, but it is trying very hard to ruin the experience.  I love the game while I'm playing it (and it's working), but it always leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

review_title: Wow.  This is a fantastic game.
one_reviews_text:
Heart pounding.  I jumped to a new system on my far-bound travels to Earth in a race against the alien forces nipping at my heels, a pirate was waiting.  So I targeted his weapons, swiftly disabled them and then teleported to their ship and began slowly and methodically exterminating their entire crew while taking out their engines, shields and finally their captain before hacking their cargo manifest and teleporting all their ill-gotten gains to my ship.  As a final goodbye, I teleported back to my ship and blew theirs to bits with a barrage of laser fire from my ship.

...4 jumps later I came across an alien that then ate my entire crew.

Such is life in From Other Suns.

This game is quite frankly amazing.  You get to run around your own ship with your crew repairing systems as pirates dock and try to take over, you do the same to them, you can simply target enemy vessels and blow them to kingdom come and then sell the profits to upgrade your ship, buy new weapons or even more crew-members to keep your ship in top shape (as well as provide you with extra lives when you inevitably die).  Basically, there's a hell of a lot you can do and no game is the same.  Since it's a roguealike, some games you'll be getting punished right from the start and struggle like hell to keep things together - whereas in others, you'll have a bout of luck and find weapons and resources aplenty - but there are no guarantees.

If you want an amazing experience in VR.  Look no further than this game.  Sure, in some ways it's a bit rough around the edges and it'll leave you wanting even more content - but as we're in the early days of VR, this is a fantastic example of what's waiting for us in times to come.  Don't deny yourself, buy this game...just be warned.  It's a bit addictive.

FOS has been my VR group's go-to game for a few weeks now. One of the better multiplayer experiences out there right now. You'll die a lot, but won't be able to help yourself from trying just *one* more time.. or, maybe a few more times.. :) The achievement system is great, it gives you goals to work toward even if you can't "beat" the game right away. My only criticisms: 1) While the environment LOOKS fantastic, it's relatively dead and lacks interactivity (even if not necessary for game mechanics, it really enhances immersion when you can play with things & affect the world at least a little bit).. 2) Being able to select/customize your avatar, even at the very LEAST choose M/F/robot etc, it's actually mildly confusing when we all spawn as opposite our real world sex.. and 3) it would be REALLY great to be able play co-op with MORE than just 3 people!!

Other than those though, I highly recommend this game.

review_title: Awesome, could benefit from more content
one_reviews_text: Beated the game twice in solo. Also died a lot, once by the hand of the Void Pirate Captain (real ones now). The game is cool, graphics beautiful, the retro style enjoyable, the gameplay and guns satisfying. The permadeath makes you care about what you do and how to survive if you want to beat the game. Counter intuitive at first, the inventory is ok, even if my first "take a grenade, activate it, throw it" was a disaster... you'll get used to it. The multiplayer is awesome, but connexions are too instable and buggy. Hope the last patch fixed it. To be honest, this game is... the real thing. You will find yourself crouched, guns in hands like Ian Solo. You will find yourself running like hell because a f***ing Xenos is chasing you and your unloaded guns (where is this f***ing loader?!). You will prey for your last hackatron to hack a cargo even if it's a 5% chance to work. You will find yourself trying to inject a medkit in you veins under enemies fire, heart pounding hard because it's your last life (and they are wayyy more than you thought). You will sometimes die stupidly, because of overconfidence, and tell yourself you will never do the same reckless mistake. But you also will win, and when you do, well... You will want to restart another adventure. Because each is different. Only one thing : the game can be repetitive, even if it is always fun to play. It could benefit from a little more content/maps/enemy type/weapon type/ missions/boss variety. Oh yeah, there are bosses too :) Buy it, play it, get achievments, win it, restart with a more kickass ship, play again until your eyes bleed. Have fun.

I want to give this 5 stars but I'm having serious problems with the touch controllers. While playing in seated mode my left controller will flip 90-180 degress for movement control. This makes it very difficult to move around and not very fun.

This has everything that was good about FTL and makes it feel much more personal.  Fleeing across the galaxy from a pursuing menace, gathering salvage, fuel and ammunition from anywhere you can to fund upgrades and keep you moving.  Where this game stands apart from FTL is the away-team missions - teleportig into a station or ship and clearing out pirates, rogue robots or aliens.  The gunplay feels good, and you can duck behind cover or around corners to avoid incoming fire.  The enemy AI is mostly effective as well, with enemies moving to flank you if you stay put too long.  Bosses are a bit easier though, with their movements and attacks restricted to a few well telegraphed patterns.  The final boss feels exceptionally easy compared to the endless swarm of bots you'll face in the firmware upload missions.  Still, the game plays well in solo and shines in co-op.  Definitely a must-own title.

review_title: Best coop game in my library

Tons of fun when playing with friends or strangers in the universe.  I really love being the captain of my own ship and making decisions for my crew (human or AI).  The experience as a whole is great allowing you to play from a first person perspective while adventuring among the stars.  

PROS: Rogue like design where death is permanent and if you lose all "meat bags" on the ship, you lose and it deletes your saved game.  Good FPS mechanics.  Random encounters keep each game fresh and fun.

CONS: Inventory system takes some getting used to; unintuitive at first, but you do get the hang of it after some time.  Encounters tend to get repetetive... until you encounter the Xenos (then you cry like a baby).  Also, earth is in danger from advanced aliens (similar to FTL), so you can't really stick around and just explore a single area, lest the aliens destroy earth.  However, they aren't break-neck fast, so you can do some exploration and have time to make slight detours if you want/need.  So far, there is only one ship you can pilot.  Would be nice if you could capture ships.

Overall, a very fun game, especially with friends and random people online.  It really hits the space-renegade spot we've all been waiting for!  If the developers continue to add features to this game, I think it will be one of the best Rift experiences out there!

review_title: Great Coop Game, Room to be Even Better

Solo this game is quite challenging; with one other person it becomes amazingly fun.

The good:
-Good basic game loop
-Many different options for movement
-No issues with multiplayer connectivity observed

The bad:
-Enemy AI is very rudimentary
-Difficulty scaling across a session can be very spiky, particularly when solo
-The variety of missions/encounters is fairly low, so you see the same missions frequently (though the maps are randomly created)
-Minor bugs (items occasionally disappearing when dropped, had a teleporter send me into a bulkhead once until the game was restarted, etc)

Bottom line:
Well worth the price, and I'd personally actually welcome an expansion of the game at a later date with additional missions, weapon types, ships, etc for a moderate fee (say around $10)  The base game is a good platform and the rogue-like generation makes it something which could easily be expanded upon.

review_title: One of the best vr games available
one_reviews_text:
Completed the game twice so far (once in co-op and once in singleplayer) and still have a lot to unlock. 

You start out with a basic ship (you can unlock up to 7 different ships) and need to make your way back to Earth before the alien mothership reaches it. Each system you jump to has the chance to have a random event or mission that are full of random weapons, enemies and boss fights.

The game is rogue-lite so permadeath results in having to start from the beginning. The game is designed so that every playthrough will feel different and the weapons you will find will vary in style and stats, You won't come across every mission in a single playthrough either (theres a lot of content).

I've personally found that this game rewards persistence and adaptation. Overall this game is great but it is on the cusp of the best VR shooter out there.  It just needs more lootable and interactive invironments.  Even more weapons maybe armor and crafting!

review_title: Really fun, but not without issue.
one_reviews_text: Think FTL but in VR with more of a focus on missions that send you to hostile space stations, and a little less focus on the space combat. There is also a Borderlands-esque loot system, where the guns you find have different stats and elements on them that get better as you progress. There are also a fairly decent variety of gun types from what I've seen so far. The issue is the difficulty spike. The enemies really quickly get stronger, particularly the robot enemies. After only about 3 space station explorations I started encountering robots that shoot explosive rockets. I would fight two or three at a time, and each one fires a barrage of three rockets in their attacks. All it takes is two hits to kill you. This leads to the only option being to run away as fast as you can while taking pot shots at them, hoping you kill them before you run out of ammo or places to run to. It doesn't help that the interface for changing your weapon or taking out a consumable is clunky. You press a button with one hand to bring your inventory up in front of you, while grabbing the item you want with the other. Not only does this fully disarm you while changing equipment, but often times while trying to grab a specific item or gun I'd randomly grab a different one than I had highlighted. I would have prefered if tapping a button brought up a static inventory, so I wouldn't have to desperately scramble to pull out a health hypo (which is an item that definitely should be quick to access) in the middle of a fight. All in all though, it is one of the better VR games I have played, I do thoroughly enjoy it, and I just hope the devs tweak some things here and there to make it even better.

review_title: Meh.  Off to a slow start.
one_reviews_text:
My first impression was that the game looks interesting. During the intro, I was concerned that textures had failed to load, though the jittery wireframed look of the training rooms was apparently intentional.  

I was excited to try the 'smooth' movement option, but found it induced motion sickness almost IMMEDIATELY.  I'm not sure I can fault the game for this.  The problem with smooth movement is that in the real world, your focus is based on the position of your EYES, not your head.  So until VR supports iris scanning, panning while moving will continue to induce motion sickness.

Haven't tried multiplayer, but single player mode quickly devolves as soon as the game starts.  Wandering around the ship, I could find NOTHING to interact with for over 30 minutes before finally getting bored and simply quitting the game.  I'm hoping that multiplayer will prove more interesting, but for now, I feel I've wasted my dollars already.
